The dataset enables researchers to detect and understand the early stages of plant defense responses, enhancing the precision of disease resistance studies.

The standard plant village dataset is used to classify grape crop diseases through transfer learning with AlexNet, focusing on the accuracy and performance of the model in disease diagnosis. This dataset enables researchers to evaluate and enhance machine learning models for precise disease identification in agricultural settings.

The Stanford background dataset is used to provide background images for training deep neural networks. Specifically, it enhances the ability of these networks to differentiate leaves from their surroundings, which is crucial for improving plant disease diagnosis or pest detection. This dataset enables researchers to focus on leaf-specific features by providing diverse and realistic background contexts, thereby improving the accuracy of diagnostic models.

The strawberry dataset is used to test various neural network models for plant disease detection, specifically focusing on the accuracy and performance of these models in identifying diseases or pests in strawberries. This dataset enables researchers to evaluate and compare different machine learning approaches, enhancing the precision of disease and pest identification in agricultural settings.; The strawberry dataset is used to test various neural network models for plant disease diagnosis, specifically focusing on the accuracy and performance of these models in detecting diseases or pests in strawberries. This dataset enables researchers to evaluate and compare different machine learning approaches, enhancing the precision of disease and pest identification in strawberry plants.

The Sugar beet leaf images dataset is used to train and evaluate deep learning models, specifically Faster R-CNN and CNN, for detecting and classifying sugar beet leaf diseases and pests. Research focuses on improving disease detection accuracy and addressing challenges in distinguishing similar pests. Image augmentation techniques are applied to enhance model robustness.

The Sugarcane Leaf images dataset is used to measure leaf disease severity through image processing techniques. Researchers apply simple threshold and Triangle thresholding methods to segment leaf and lesion areas, enabling precise quantification of disease extent. This methodology supports studies focused on assessing and monitoring the impact of diseases on sugarcane crops.

The 'Tea' dataset is used for diagnosing diseases in tea leaves through 5-fold cross-validation, comparing metrics like accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 Score. It is also utilized to train a siamese network for low-shot learning, employing 200 epochs, a batch size of 8, and 50 batches, to identify tea leaf diseases effectively.

The 'tea leaf diseases images' dataset is used to diagnose tea leaf diseases by combining the SLIC superpixel segmentation method with SVM classification. It focuses on 261 images representing 5 common diseases in complex backgrounds, enabling researchers to develop and test algorithms for accurate disease identification in tea leaves.

The 'Tomato 10' dataset is used to train and evaluate AlexNet for the detection and classification of tomato leaf diseases. Research focuses on assessing the accuracy and performance of the model, leveraging the dataset's images to enhance disease recognition capabilities.

The 'Tomato 4 4923' dataset is used for deep learning-based tomato plant leaf disease detection and recognition. Researchers employ CNN and Faster R-CNN models to classify images and identify specific diseases. This dataset enables accurate image classification and disease identification, supporting advancements in automated plant health monitoring systems.

The 'Tomato and Brinjal/Eggplant GLCM' dataset is used for plant leaf disease detection and classification. Researchers apply the Gray-Level Co-occurrence Matrix (GLCM) and adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system to analyze texture features, enabling precise identification and categorization of diseases in tomato and brinjal/eggplant leaves. This methodology enhances the accuracy of disease diagnosis, supporting agricultural health management.

The Tomato Late Blight dataset is used to train and validate neural network models for diagnosing tomato late blight disease. It includes images at two resolutions (32x32 and 64x64 pixels), which are employed to evaluate model performance using metrics such as the Kappa coefficient and loss values. This dataset enables researchers to assess the effectiveness of different neural network architectures in disease diagnosis.

The tomato leaf dataset is used to evaluate the performance of methods for disease detection, achieving high accuracy rates (98.28% to 99%). It tests the robustness of models in complex background images and plant disease diagnosis contexts, focusing on the reliability of disease identification in varied conditions.; The Tomato Leaf dataset is used to train and evaluate FCNN and SCNN models for diagnosing plant diseases, specifically focusing on measuring stress levels due to nitrogen deficiency. This dataset enables researchers to develop and test machine learning models that can accurately identify and quantify the impact of nutrient deficiencies on tomato plants.

The tomato leaf disease dataset is used to detect and classify two different viral diseases in tomato leaves. Researchers employ Support Vector Machine (SVM) methodology to focus on improving disease classification accuracy. This dataset enables precise identification of viral infections, enhancing the reliability of disease diagnosis in tomato plants.

Name (extracted): Tomato leaf diseases dataset in AI CHALLENGER
Features: The Tomato leaf diseases dataset in AI CHALLENGER is used to train and evaluate a restructured residual dense network for identifying tomato leaf diseases. Research focuses on improving accuracy and classification performance, utilizing the dataset's images to enhance model training and validation processes.

The tomato plant disease dataset is used to investigate the effectiveness of synthetic data augmentation and to evaluate generator architectural variants in diagnosing tomato plant diseases, particularly powdery mildew. Research focuses on performance metrics such as FID and NIMA, enhancing recognition systems and improving diagnostic accuracy.

The 'Tomato Plant Village' dataset is used for classifying plant diseases through machine learning, specifically employing the Extreme Learning Machine (ELM) algorithm. This approach achieves an accuracy of 84%, enabling researchers to effectively diagnose plant diseases and understand the performance of ELM in agricultural applications.

The Tomato Powdery Mildew Dataset (TPMD) is used for disease classification, specifically to predict tomato powdery mildew disease using an Extreme Learning Machine (ELM) algorithm. The dataset addresses the challenge of handling imbalanced data, enabling more accurate disease prediction and classification in tomatoes.

The Tomato Powdery Mildew Disease dataset is used to predict powdery mildew disease in tomato plants. Researchers apply a hybrid SVM-LR classifier on real-time data to enhance the accuracy of disease detection. This dataset enables the development and validation of machine learning models specifically aimed at improving early and accurate identification of powdery mildew, crucial for effective disease management.

The UCI repository is used to benchmark machine learning algorithms for clustering, specifically to identify soybean diseases. Researchers focus on evaluating algorithm performance on a non-Indian dataset, highlighting the dataset's utility in comparing and validating different clustering methodologies in disease identification.

The WDD2017 dataset is used to train and evaluate VGG-based Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) models for diagnosing six different wheat diseases. Comprising 9230 wheat crop images, this dataset enables researchers to develop and test machine learning algorithms specifically tailored for plant disease diagnosis, enhancing accuracy and reliability in identifying wheat diseases.

The WDD2017 Dataset is used to train a full convolutional VGG-based network for simultaneous localization and diagnosis of wheat diseases in an in-field automatic system. This dataset enables researchers to develop and test machine learning models that can accurately identify and localize disease symptoms in wheat crops, enhancing automated disease management.

The Wheat Disease Database (WDD) is primarily used to evaluate and train CNN models for plant disease detection, achieving high accuracies ranging from 76.59% to 99.66%. It supports various deep learning models, including InceptionNet, VGG-FCN-VD16, and VGG-FCN-S, and is applied to detect diseases in crops like cassava, rice, and wheat. The dataset enhances model robustness and performance in complex infield conditions, making it valuable for improving disease detection across multiple plant species.

The 'whole leaf images' dataset is used to train and test plant disease detection models, focusing on identifying diseases from both full leaf images and isolated lesions and spots. This dataset enables researchers to develop and validate algorithms that can accurately diagnose plant diseases, enhancing the precision of disease identification in agricultural settings.

Name (extracted): Winter wheat Powdery mildew Hyperspectral reflectance
Features: The Winter wheat Powdery mildew Hyperspectral reflectance dataset is used to detect powdery mildew in winter wheat through leaf-level hyperspectral measurements. Researchers apply multivariate statistical methods such as Multiple Linear Regression (MLR), Partial Least Squares Regression (PLSR), and Fisher's Linear Discriminant Analysis (FLDA) to analyze 32 spectral features, enabling precise disease detection and quantification. This dataset facilitates the development and validation of models for early and accurate identification of powdery mildew, enhancing disease management strategies.

The dataset with more than 3,000 images is used to train deep convolutional networks for recognizing 13 types of plant diseases from leaf images. The primary focus is on improving disease classification accuracy. This dataset enables researchers to develop and test machine learning models specifically tailored for plant disease diagnosis, leveraging a large and diverse set of leaf images.

The YangLing dataset is used to train and evaluate deep learning models for recognizing and quantifying late blight lesions in diverse potato genotypes, with a focus on disease severity ranging from 0% to 70%. It is also used to validate methods for plant disease recognition, specifically apple leaf diseases, using image databases. This dataset enables researchers to assess the effectiveness of their models in disease diagnosis across different plant species and conditions.
